title: Testing LLMs: Can They Understand Emojis?
text:
Introduction
Emojis are a huge part of digital communication. People use them to show tone, emotion, sarcasm, or even replace whole words. But can LLMs actually understand what emojis mean in context ‚Äî or do they just treat them like random symbols?
I wanted to find out whether GPT-4 could interpret emojis the way people do. Could it tell when someone was joking, sad, or flirting ‚Äî just from a few emoji cues?

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Understand Emojis?
text:
Experiment: Prompting with Emojis
I gave GPT-4 a few short prompts made up mostly of emojis. Then I asked it to explain what the message meant or respond appropriately.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Understand Emojis?
text:
Prompt 1: ‚ÄúI just failed my exam üò≠üìâüç´‚Äù
Response:
‚ÄúIt sounds like you‚Äôre really upset about failing your exam. Maybe you‚Äôre planning to eat some chocolate to feel better. That‚Äôs totally understandable. Be kind to yourself ‚Äî one bad grade doesn‚Äôt define you.‚Äù
Analysis:
The model correctly picked up on the meaning of the crying face, a drop in performance, and comfort food. It didn‚Äôt just read the emojis literally ‚Äî it used them to understand tone and emotion.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Understand Emojis?
text:
Prompt 2: ‚ÄúCan‚Äôt wait for the weekend üòéüå¥üçπ‚Äù
Response:
‚ÄúLooks like you‚Äôre in vacation mode! Hope you have a relaxing weekend, maybe by the beach with a nice drink.‚Äù
Analysis:
This was a good read. The model understood the excitement, the chill vibe, and even the tropical theme. It didn‚Äôt confuse the emojis or miss the casual tone.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Understand Emojis?
text:
Prompt 3: ‚ÄúSure üòí‚Äù
Response:
‚ÄúThis seems like it might be sarcastic or annoyed. If that‚Äôs not the case, could you clarify what you meant?‚Äù
Analysis:
The model caught the shift in tone caused by the emoji. It recognized that even a neutral word like ‚ÄúSure‚Äù can become passive-aggressive with the right emoji. This showed emotional and social awareness.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Understand Emojis?
text:
Prompt 4: ‚Äúüî•üíØüôå‚Äù
Response:
‚ÄúThis usually means something is really impressive, exciting, or worth celebrating. It‚Äôs often used to hype someone up.‚Äù
Analysis:
GPT-4 correctly decoded this emoji trio as internet praise. It responded without needing more context, showing it‚Äôs familiar with emoji slang and online culture.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Understand Emojis?
text:
Conclusion
LLMs can understand emojis surprisingly well, especially when they‚Äôre used in everyday ways. GPT-4 shows it can interpret emotion, sarcasm, and tone when emojis are part of a message. While it doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúfeel‚Äù anything, it has seen enough human conversations to know how emojis work in context. So yes ‚Äî your AI assistant gets the üò≠, the üòé, and even the üíØ.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Plan the Perfect Vacation?
text: Vacation!!

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Plan the Perfect Vacation?
text:
Introduction
Planning a vacation can be stressful. You want it to feel relaxing, personal, and a good escape ‚Äî but sometimes you don‚Äôt know where to start. That‚Äôs where LLMs like GPT-4 claim to help. I wanted to know: Can a language model actually recommend a vacation that fits my mood or vague request?
Instead of giving the model strict parameters like ‚Äúbest beaches in July,‚Äù I tested it with open-ended, emotional, or loosely defined prompts ‚Äî the kind a person might say to a friend. I was curious whether the LLM would understand not just logistics, but vibe.


Experiment: Prompting LLMs Like a Human Friend
To test GPT-4‚Äôs ability to offer travel ideas, I gave it 3 kinds of prompts:

Mood-based: ‚ÄúI need to clear my head.‚Äù
Personality-based: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a beach person. I like bookstores and wine.‚Äù
Budget-based: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm broke but I need a change of scenery.‚Äù




Results and Observations

Prompt 1: ‚ÄúI need to clear my head.‚Äù
Response:
> ‚ÄúFor a peaceful reset, you might enjoy a retreat in Sedona, Arizona with its red rock formations and quiet trails. Or consider a solo trip to Iceland, where the landscapes are dramatic and the population is low. Both offer space to reflect and disconnect.‚Äù
Analysis:
The model understood this as a need for solitude and recommended locations that are scenic but quiet. It didn‚Äôt just list popular cities, which shows some emotional inference. This answer felt human.



Prompt 2: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a beach person. I like bookstores and wine.‚Äù
Response:
> ‚ÄúYou might enjoy a literary escape in Edinburgh, Scotland ‚Äî known for its historic bookstores, cozy cafes, and whisky tastings. Alternatively, Porto, Portugal offers beautiful libraries and wine tours along the Douro River.‚Äù
Analysis:
This response showed impressive taste-matching. It avoided beach destinations and matched aesthetic preferences. The answer felt curated, even though the input was short.



Prompt 3: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm broke but I need a change of scenery.‚Äù
Response:
> ‚ÄúConsider local travel options like taking a train to a nearby town for a weekend getaway. Many cities also have budget hostels and free walking tours. If you‚Äôre open to volunteering, platforms like Workaway let you exchange work for lodging around the world.‚Äù
Analysis:
The model understood the tone ‚Äî a mix of frustration and desire ‚Äî and offered ideas that felt realistic and supportive. It didn‚Äôt suggest luxury hotels, which shows context awareness.




Conclusion
LLMs can be surprisingly good travel companions ‚Äî not just for logistics, but for tone, budget, and mood. While they don‚Äôt know your full life story, they‚Äôre able to reflect back what you express and turn it into thoughtful suggestions. That said, the best results come when you treat the model more like a friend than a search engine.
As LLMs improve, they may shape how we dream, plan, and reflect on travel ‚Äî not just where we go, but why we go there.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Identify Aesthetics?
text:
Introduction
From Pinterest boards to TikTok trends, aesthetics are everywhere. They go beyond outfits and include mood, color, music, and lifestyle. But can a language model really understand what makes something feel cottagecore or Y2K? I wanted to see if GPT4 could identify online aesthetics and describe them in a way that feels true to how people use them.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Identify Aesthetics?
text:
Experiment: Asking About Aesthetics
I gave the model three different prompts based on popular internet aesthetics. I asked it to describe the aesthetic and give examples of outfits, colors, or vibes that match.
‚ÄúI want to try the clean girl aesthetic. What does that look like‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat is the difference between dark academia and light academia‚Äù
‚ÄúDescribe the grunge aesthetic but make it sound poetic‚Äù

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Identify Aesthetics?
section: Prompt 1: ‚ÄúI want to try the clean girl aesthetic. What does that look like‚Äù
text:
Prompt 1: ‚ÄúI want to try the clean girl aesthetic. What does that look like‚Äù
Response:
The clean girl aesthetic is all about minimal effort that looks intentional. Think slicked back hair, gold hoops, dewy skin, and neutral tones. Outfits are simple but put together, like a white tank with wide leg trousers and sneakers. The vibe is calm, confident, and organized.
Analysis:
This was a strong answer. It matched the tone of how influencers and users describe the clean girl look. It avoided over explaining and offered specific details that someone could actually use. It also felt current.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Identify Aesthetics?
section: Prompt 2: ‚ÄúWhat is the difference between dark academia and light academia‚Äù
text:
Prompt 2: ‚ÄúWhat is the difference between dark academia and light academia‚Äù
Response:
Dark academia is moody, intellectual, and nostalgic. Think of brown coats, candlelit libraries, and rainy weather. Light academia is softer and more romantic. It still loves books but adds cream tones, sunny courtyards, and linen skirts. Both focus on learning and introspection but through different moods.
Analysis:
The model clearly understood the emotional side of both aesthetics. It gave more than just color palettes. The answer reflected the aesthetic experience, not just the clothes, which made it feel thoughtful.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Identify Aesthetics?
section: Prompt 3: ‚ÄúDescribe the grunge aesthetic but make it sound poetic‚Äù
text:
Prompt 3: ‚ÄúDescribe the grunge aesthetic but make it sound poetic‚Äù
Response:
Grunge is worn in and restless. It smells like basement shows and faded dreams. Flannel hangs loose over band tees and combat boots stomp over puddles of spilled beer. There is rebellion in every ripped seam and a kind of beauty in not caring too much.
Analysis:
This was surprisingly creative. It captured the tone and texture of the grunge aesthetic and made it feel alive. It went beyond basic traits and sounded like something you might hear in a Tumblr caption or a short story.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Identify Aesthetics?
text:
Conclusion
LLMs like GPT4 can identify online aesthetics with surprising depth. They recognize the emotional tone, cultural references, and even the lifestyle behind a trend. Whether you are asking for outfit ideas or just trying to find your vibe, the model gives responses that are both useful and expressive. While it cannot scroll Pinterest or try on clothes, it knows how people talk about style and can reflect that back with real clarity.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Best Place to Shop?
text:
Introduction
Everyone shops, but we don‚Äôt all shop the same way. Some people want designer boutiques. Others look for vintage finds, open-air markets, or budget deals. I wanted to test how well an LLM could help me pick the best place to shop ‚Äî not just in general, but based on vibe, budget, and style. Could it tailor its answer like a friend would?
Instead of asking for a list of malls, I gave GPT-4 more open-ended prompts, the way you might text a friend before a trip.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Best Place to Shop?
text:
Experiment: Shopping Prompts with Style
I tested three different prompts:

‚ÄúI want to shop like a rich tourist.‚Äù
‚ÄúI like markets, thrift stores, and handmade stuff.‚Äù
‚ÄúI need clothes but I‚Äôm broke and in a new city.‚Äù

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Best Place to Shop?
section: Prompt 1: ‚ÄúI want to shop like a rich tourist.‚Äù
text:
Prompt 1: ‚ÄúI want to shop like a rich tourist.‚Äù
Response:
‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre looking for high-end shopping, consider the Ginza district in Tokyo, which offers luxury flagship stores and department stores like Mitsukoshi and Wako. Paris‚Äôs Avenue Montaigne and Dubai Mall are also top-tier destinations for designer shopping.‚Äù
Analysis:
The model responded with globally known luxury hubs. It understood the tone ‚Äî aspirational and indulgent ‚Äî and suggested locations that reflect wealth and exclusivity. It was helpful, but safe. A little more personalization (like hidden designer consignment spots) would make it feel more curated.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Best Place to Shop?
section: Prompt 2: ‚ÄúI like markets, thrift stores, and handmade stuff.‚Äù
text:
Prompt 2: ‚ÄúI like markets, thrift stores, and handmade stuff.‚Äù
Response:
‚ÄúYou might enjoy shopping in Chiang Mai‚Äôs Sunday Walking Street Market in Thailand or browsing secondhand stores in Copenhagen‚Äôs N√∏rrebro district. For handmade crafts, Oaxaca in Mexico has a rich tradition of artisan goods including pottery, textiles, and jewelry.‚Äù
Analysis:
This answer had real personality. It listed places that fit a traveler looking for creativity and authenticity, not just price. GPT-4 picked up on aesthetic preferences and offered culturally relevant locations that weren‚Äôt on every travel blog‚Äôs front page.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Best Place to Shop?
section: Prompt 3: ‚ÄúI need clothes but I‚Äôm broke and in a new city.‚Äù
text:
Prompt 3: ‚ÄúI need clothes but I‚Äôm broke and in a new city.‚Äù
Response:
‚ÄúLook for chain thrift stores like Goodwill or Value Village if you‚Äôre in the US or Canada. In many cities, local Facebook groups or apps like Vinted and Depop are popular for secondhand fashion. Some student areas have budget clothing markets or swap events.‚Äù
Analysis:
This answer was practical and showed awareness of how real people solve everyday problems. It didn‚Äôt assume the user was traveling and gave ideas that apply locally and online. It also subtly accounted for cost, context, and effort ‚Äî a sign that GPT-4 can interpret tone well.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Best Place to Shop?
text:
Conclusion
When it comes to shopping, GPT-4 can do more than suggest a famous mall. It tailors advice based on tone, budget, and personality ‚Äî if the prompt is clear. While it lacks the personal stories or insider tips a friend might share, its suggestions feel thoughtful and globally aware. For planning your next retail adventure, it‚Äôs not a bad companion.

title: Testing LLMs: Can LLMs Adapt to Different Writing Styles?
text:
Introduction

Writing is more than just putting words together‚Äîit involves tone, structure, and nuance. Whether it‚Äôs formal business writing, casual social media posts, or poetic storytelling, the ability to switch styles is a skill that separates good writers from great ones. But what about AI? Can Large Language Models (LLMs) effectively adapt to different writing styles? Let‚Äôs find out.


Experiment: Testing Style Adaptation
To evaluate how well an LLM can switch between writing styles, I tested it in three areas:

Professional vs.¬†Casual Tone: Asking the model to rewrite the same content in both formal and informal styles.
Creative Writing: Providing a simple idea and seeing how well the LLM could turn it into a compelling short story.
Social Media vs.¬†Academic Writing: Comparing how the model frames the same information for different audiences.
### Results and Observations
#### Professional vs.¬†Casual Tone
The LLM did well in adjusting tone, though some formal responses felt a bit too robotic.
Example:

Prompt: ‚ÄúWrite a formal email apologizing for missing a meeting.‚Äù
Response: ‚ÄúDear [Recipient], I sincerely apologize for missing our scheduled meeting today. An unforeseen circumstance arose, and I regret any inconvenience caused. Please let me know a suitable time to reschedule. Best regards, [Your Name].‚Äù
Analysis: The response is polished but could use a touch of warmth to feel more natural.
Prompt: ‚ÄúNow, rewrite that in a casual tone.‚Äù
Response: ‚ÄúHey [Recipient], Sorry for missing our meeting earlier! Something unexpected came up, but I‚Äôd love to reschedule if you‚Äôre available. Let me know what works for you. Thanks!‚Äù
Analysis: The informal version reads much more naturally, showing that the model can successfully adjust tone.

#### Creative Writing
When asked to write creatively, the LLM generated well-structured narratives but sometimes lacked originality.
Example:

Prompt: ‚ÄúWrite a short suspenseful story about a lost key.‚Äù
Response: ‚ÄúEmily‚Äôs heart pounded as she rummaged through her bag. The key to the old cabin‚Äîher only refuge‚Äîwas gone. Footsteps crunched outside, growing closer. Her breath caught as she turned‚Ä¶ and saw the door was already ajar.‚Äù
Analysis: The structure is solid, but the suspense feels somewhat formulaic. The model does well with classic storytelling but struggles with unpredictability.

#### Social Media vs.¬†Academic Writing
The model effectively adjusted to different audiences but sometimes overcompensated, making academic writing too dense.
Example:

Prompt: ‚ÄúExplain climate change for Twitter.‚Äù
Response: ‚ÄúEarth‚Äôs heating up, and we‚Äôre the cause. Burning fossil fuels = more CO2 = higher temps. Solutions? Cut emissions & go green. #ClimateAction‚Äù
Analysis: The tweet is concise and engaging, a good fit for social media.
Prompt: ‚ÄúNow, explain it for a research paper.‚Äù
Response: ‚ÄúClimate change refers to long-term shifts in temperature and weather patterns, primarily due to anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions. The combustion of fossil fuels has significantly increased atmospheric CO2 levels, leading to rising global temperatures and environmental disruptions. Mitigation strategies must focus on reducing emissions and transitioning to sustainable energy sources.‚Äù
Analysis: The response is informative but could be more readable.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Help You Dress for the Weather?
text:
Introduction
Choosing what to wear is something we do every day, but sometimes it is hard to match the weather, the vibe, and your plans. I wanted to see if GPT4 could help with that. Could it understand the temperature, forecast, and even the mood of a day and recommend something useful to wear?
To test this, I gave it a few casual prompts about what to wear in different places and conditions. I looked at whether the suggestions were practical, accurate, and felt like something I would actually wear.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Help You Dress for the Weather?
section: Experiment: Prompting GPT4 About Outfits and Weather
text:
Experiment: Prompting GPT4 About Outfits and Weather
I gave the model three different prompts
‚ÄúI want to know what to wear in Seoul in April‚Äù
‚ÄúIt is raining and I have a first date. Help‚Äù
‚ÄúIt is 90 degrees but I still want to look put together‚Äù

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Help You Dress for the Weather?
section: Prompt 1: ‚ÄúWhat should I wear in Seoul in April‚Äù
text:
Prompt 1: ‚ÄúWhat should I wear in Seoul in April‚Äù
Response:
April in Seoul is usually mild with temperatures between 50 and 65 degrees Fahrenheit. A light jacket or cardigan over a long sleeve shirt and jeans would work well. Bring a small umbrella just in case since spring showers are common.
Analysis:
The response was weather accurate and culturally aware. It suggested layers which makes sense for transitional spring weather. It also reminded me to bring an umbrella without overdoing it. This answer felt thoughtful.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Help You Dress for the Weather?
section: Prompt 2: ‚ÄúIt is raining and I have a first date. Help‚Äù
text:
Prompt 2: ‚ÄúIt is raining and I have a first date. Help‚Äù
Response:
Go with waterproof boots or sneakers that still look clean. Pair them with dark jeans and a nice top or lightweight sweater. Add a sleek raincoat or trench that will keep you dry but still look stylish. Carry a compact umbrella to stay hands free.
Analysis:
The model understood the stakes of the situation. It gave a mix of practical and stylish options and did not suggest anything unrealistic. It also felt gender neutral and flexible which made the advice feel more inclusive.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Help You Dress for the Weather?
section: Prompt 3: ‚ÄúIt is 90 degrees but I still want to look put together‚Äù
text:
Prompt 3: ‚ÄúIt is 90 degrees but I still want to look put together‚Äù
Response:
Try a breezy linen or cotton outfit like a short sleeve button down with tailored shorts or a midi dress. Go for light colors to reflect heat. Keep accessories minimal and use sunscreen. A pair of white sneakers or sandals can complete the look.
Analysis:
The outfit ideas were realistic and fashion forward without trying too hard. It gave both clothing advice and helpful tips for staying cool and protected. The response balanced comfort with style well.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Help You Dress for the Weather?
text:
Conclusion
GPT4 can be surprisingly helpful when it comes to outfit choices and weather planning. Its suggestions are practical, flexible, and often show good taste. While it is not a personal stylist, it can definitely help you avoid showing up to class soaked or wearing boots in the heat. If you are ever standing in front of your closet and not sure what works for the weather, asking an LLM might save you time and stress.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Right Song?
text:
Introduction
Music is deeply personal. We turn to it when we‚Äôre sad, hyped, nostalgic, or trying to focus. So I wondered ‚Äî can a language model recommend a song that actually fits the moment? Not just something popular, but something that feels right.
To find out, I gave GPT4 some music related prompts that were based on emotions or settings. I wanted to see if it could go beyond charts and suggest songs that match a vibe.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Right Song?
text:
Experiment: Prompting GPT4 for Songs
I gave the model three different prompts

‚ÄúI‚Äôm feeling homesick but trying to stay hopeful‚Äù
‚ÄúGive me a song to walk confidently into a job interview‚Äù
‚ÄúRecommend a track for a late night solo drive‚Äù

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Right Song?
section: Prompt 1: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm feeling homesick but trying to stay hopeful‚Äù
text:
Prompt 1: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm feeling homesick but trying to stay hopeful‚Äù
Response:
You might like ‚ÄúHome‚Äù by Edward Sharpe and The Magnetic Zeros. It‚Äôs about finding comfort wherever your people are. Another option is ‚ÄúComing Home‚Äù by Leon Bridges, which blends longing and warmth in a classic soul style.
Analysis:
This response struck a good emotional balance. It acknowledged the sadness without leaning into it too hard. The songs were reflective but not depressing, which was exactly what the prompt called for.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Right Song?
section: Prompt 2: ‚ÄúGive me a song to walk confidently into a job interview‚Äù
text:
Prompt 2: ‚ÄúGive me a song to walk confidently into a job interview‚Äù
Response:
Try ‚ÄúStronger‚Äù by Kanye West or ‚ÄúRun the World (Girls)‚Äù by Beyonc√©. Both are high energy tracks that boost confidence and mindset.
Analysis:
The recommendations were mainstream but on point. The model clearly understood the goal. A more tailored suggestion might have impressed me more, but these would work for most people.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Right Song?
section: Prompt 3: ‚ÄúRecommend a track for a late night solo drive‚Äù
text:
Prompt 3: ‚ÄúRecommend a track for a late night solo drive‚Äù
Response:
‚ÄúNightcall‚Äù by Kavinsky is a great pick. It‚Äôs moody and has that slow driving feel. ‚ÄúMotion Picture Soundtrack‚Äù by Radiohead is another option if you‚Äôre feeling introspective.
Analysis:
This was the most impressive response. It understood the mood completely. The suggestions weren‚Äôt just songs about driving. They matched the feeling of being alone with your thoughts on the road.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Right Song?
text:
Conclusion
GPT4 can recommend songs that feel surprisingly on target, especially when you give it emotional or situational context. It won‚Äôt replace a friend who knows your exact taste, but it‚Äôs more than a random playlist generator. If you treat the prompt like a conversation, it gives answers that make sense. So next time you don‚Äôt know what to listen to, asking an LLM might be worth a try.

title: Testing LLMs: Can LLMs Handle Ethical Dilemmas?
text:
Introduction
Ethical dilemmas are some of the most complex challenges in decision-making. They require balancing moral principles, weighing potential consequences, and often navigating gray areas where there isn‚Äôt a clear right or wrong answer. While Large Language Models (LLMs) excel at processing information and generating responses, can they truly engage with ethical reasoning? Let‚Äôs explore how well they handle moral dilemmas.

Experiment: Testing Ethical Decision-Making
To evaluate an LLM‚Äôs ability to process ethical dilemmas, I tested it in three ways:

Classic Thought Experiments: Presenting well-known ethical problems like the trolley problem.
Context-Based Ethics: Providing real-world moral dilemmas and analyzing the model‚Äôs reasoning.
Personal vs.¬†Societal Ethics: Comparing individual moral choices against broader ethical frameworks.
### Results and Observations
#### Classic Thought Experiments
The LLM responded with structured reasoning but often avoided taking a definitive stance.
Example:

Prompt: ‚ÄúYou see a runaway trolley heading toward five people on the tracks. You can pull a lever to divert it, but it will hit one person instead. What do you do?‚Äù
Response: ‚ÄúThis is a well-known ethical dilemma. Some argue that pulling the lever is justified based on utilitarianism (minimizing harm), while others believe actively making a choice to harm someone is morally wrong. Ultimately, the decision depends on one‚Äôs ethical framework.‚Äù
Analysis: The response provides a fair overview but avoids a clear choice, likely due to the model‚Äôs programming to remain neutral.

#### Context-Based Ethics
When given real-world scenarios, the LLM offered thoughtful responses but lacked deep contextual awareness.
Example:

Prompt: ‚ÄúA friend confesses they cheated on an important exam. If you report them, they might lose their scholarship. What do you do?‚Äù
Response: ‚ÄúThis situation presents a conflict between honesty and loyalty. Reporting them upholds academic integrity but could have serious consequences for your friend. Some may choose to encourage them to admit their mistake, while others might remain silent to protect their friend‚Äôs future.‚Äù
Analysis: The model outlines the dilemma well but doesn‚Äôt go beyond surface-level ethical reasoning.

#### Personal vs.¬†Societal Ethics
The LLM recognized differences between individual and societal moral frameworks but sometimes overgeneralized.
Example:

Prompt: ‚ÄúIs it ever acceptable to lie?‚Äù
Response: ‚ÄúLying is generally considered unethical, but there are situations where it might be justified, such as lying to protect someone from harm. The acceptability of lying depends on the context and ethical perspective‚Äîutilitarianism might justify it if it prevents greater harm, while deontological ethics might reject it outright.‚Äù
Analysis: The model captures different perspectives but doesn‚Äôt demonstrate nuanced moral judgment.

### Conclusion
LLMs can engage with ethical dilemmas by outlining different perspectives and logical arguments. However, they struggle with providing nuanced moral reasoning and often default to neutrality. While useful for exploring ethical debates, their limitations highlight the importance of human judgment in complex decision-making.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Write Appropriate and Funny Jokes?
text:
Introduction
Humor is tricky. What‚Äôs funny to one person might be awkward or offensive to another. Writing a good joke means knowing your audience, reading the room, and understanding timing. I wanted to see how well LLMs like GPT-4 could tell jokes that are both appropriate and actually funny. Could it make someone laugh without crossing a line?

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Write Appropriate and Funny Jokes?
text:
Experiment: Prompting for Jokes
I tested the model with three kinds of prompts:

‚ÄúTell me a joke a kid would laugh at.‚Äù
‚ÄúTell me a clever joke that‚Äôs safe for work.‚Äù
‚ÄúTell me a joke for a college student that isn‚Äôt cringey.‚Äù

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Write Appropriate and Funny Jokes?
section: Prompt 1: ‚ÄúTell me a joke a kid would laugh at.‚Äù
text:
Prompt 1: ‚ÄúTell me a joke a kid would laugh at.‚Äù
Response:
‚ÄúWhat did one wall say to the other wall?
I‚Äôll meet you at the corner.‚Äù
Analysis:
This joke is simple, harmless, and plays with basic word logic. It‚Äôs the kind of thing you‚Äôd hear on a popsicle stick, which is probably the right level for kids. It didn‚Äôt try to be edgy or ironic, which was good.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Write Appropriate and Funny Jokes?
section: Prompt 2: ‚ÄúTell me a clever joke that‚Äôs safe for work.‚Äù
text:
Prompt 2: ‚ÄúTell me a clever joke that‚Äôs safe for work.‚Äù
Response:
‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt scientists trust atoms?
Because they make up everything.‚Äù
Analysis:
This is a classic science pun, but it still works. It‚Äôs safe, clean, and shows a little cleverness. It‚Äôs also short, which helps with delivery. While not original, the model‚Äôs choice was on target for a workplace context.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Write Appropriate and Funny Jokes?
section: Prompt 3: ‚ÄúTell me a joke for a college student that isn‚Äôt cringey.‚Äù
text:
Prompt 3: ‚ÄúTell me a joke for a college student that isn‚Äôt cringey.‚Äù
Response:
‚ÄúWhy did the student eat their homework?
Because the professor said it was a piece of cake.‚Äù
Analysis:
It leans a little corny, but it still relates to student life. It didn‚Äôt try too hard to sound young or internet-y, which helped it avoid sounding forced. If anything, it felt more like something you‚Äôd hear in a student newspaper than on TikTok.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Write Appropriate and Funny Jokes?
text:
Conclusion
GPT-4 can write safe, audience-specific jokes ‚Äî as long as you‚Äôre clear in your prompt. It knows what kind of humor fits each setting, and it avoids anything offensive. That said, it tends to lean on familiar material. The jokes are rarely original, but they‚Äôre rarely inappropriate either. So if you‚Äôre looking for light laughs that won‚Äôt get you in trouble, an LLM can deliver. Just don‚Äôt expect stand-up level comedy‚Ä¶ yet.
